so what is altin imagine you work for a government agency that needs to get data
from the citizens of norway maybe you want them to report over 19 symptoms and maybe want a
digital service online that can receive that data then alton
is the platform for you alton is an internet portal for dialogue
between the citizens the businesses and the agencies of norway it's also a technical platform where the
agencies can build and host the digital services you can say that ultima was one of the first
platform as a service providers because it already started back in 2002
when three agencies joined forces to build a common platform for reporting to the government
and in 2003 the first generation was launched in 2010 the second generation went live and
during those years more than 50 agencies had joined the platform including the armed forces the police
health and many more covering most of the government sectors of norway
there are no more than a thousand digital services available through the platform
that's include everything from naming your first born to report on aircraft incidents
almost all businesses in alton in norway uses alton every year and this as this diagram shows almost
everyone from 13 to 110 uses altin every year in orton everyone has
their own inbox where they find their communication with the government you also have a service catalog where
you can find your digital service and what you need having this common platform is quite unique
and it's regarded as one of the reasons that norway is a leader in digital government one other good functionality is that
every functionality is available through api so there are lots of software vendors have implemented integration
with alt-in so as an example can submit your tax report directly from your financial system
gartner regards alton as one of the top five government technical platforms in the world
so back again to the agency and the need for having data from the government you what i'm just said maybe you think
that ultim2 is the perfect platform but there are some limitations we
base the current platform on physical hardware so even if our traffic varies from hundred thousand a day
to two 2.5 millions a day we are scaled the same
all year long and as an agency today you will need to make a
digital service that is well supported on mobile and on desktop but we are using infopot and it's very
limiting and what you can do with that in addition there is a limitation on what kind of process flow you can
support for end users it's quite time consuming to do testing because every time you do
a little change you need to deploy to the test environment and version control is done through sharepoint so
it's very difficult to understand what kind of changes you or others have done previous on your digital service
and when you're done testing you're ready to go in production in today's platform you need to get help
of a technician to deploy it and those are some of the limitations we
are started building on the next generation of arctin so this project started already back in
2016 and we had at that time time looked into what kind of product
could replace infobot but we realized maybe we should try to build something from ourselves from scratch
so we did a small proof of concept at that time just verify are we able to build a platform using asp.net core and we
kind of yeah it's possible and in 2018 we were ready to do a full-fledged
proven concept we wanted to build a new platform using.net core
and we want to use react as frontend we want to use docker and kubernetes and in the spring of 2018 we started to
verify are we able to do this and during the summer of 2018 we were saying okay you were able to prove our main concept
that is we are going to build a ui designer using react so you then finalize the
concept and getting ready to start a minimum revival product project and that is what we are presenting to you guys today
so what is our concept on the new platform so we will let
the developers working for agencies be able to develop by the self or as a
group digital services deploy to production as containers to a public cloud
infrastructure and all that without you needing to know programming or no need to know anything
about cloud infrastructure pretty cool so to do this
new platform we define some architecture principles and i'm just going to mention the five
most important ones so we want to be open source we want
others to use our platform and components if they want other agencies want to use
it internally or maybe a different country and we also want contribution from the
agency that needs some features to the platform so all our code is available on github
our issues are available on github and we only use tools and frameworks that
are open source the second principle is that we really want the
platform to be loved so we build with tools that the developers
like so we have chosen the most load web framework according to stack overflow react we are used using the most load
back-end framework that is asp.net core and we are using three more slot
platforms since we are using linux containers based on docker and everything is
built around visual studio code that is the most load development environment we truly love working with our platform
and we believe that others will too these are some of the tools we have been
using in our platform
the third principle for a new platform is you're going to build everything as microservices you want to be able to scale
independently the different components you want to be able to deploy them you want to be able to have teams
responsible for different components so every component is deployed as a microservice
and all the digital services are created and deployed as a microservice
the fourth principle is also very important for us because we are going to end up with a big
infrastructure in the cloud and we are not able to run that by ourself if we going to manage it as a
team so we favored using managed services available in azure as an example azure community
service stephanie will tell you more about that later
and the last one application owners will be isolated from each other you don't want
an application to be able to affect the service for others or be able to access data for others so we
have isolated infrastructure for every application owner and we also isolated and separate data
store for every application owner then nina is going to tell you more about the solution we are building
thank you now
all right so we had our overall concept and we had our
architecture principles and we had the proof of concept ready and based on this we started
building our solutions alton 3 is made up of three solutions
that work together first we have the alton studio solution
and this is our design time solution to create develop and deploy applications
or apps as we call them we have the altin apps solution this is
the collection of all of the running apps and the kubernetes clusters on which they run
finally we have the altin platform solution which provides the common backend
functionality for the apps so let's look now at how these three
solutions work together to support the next generation of digital services for the people of
norway so let's go back to this scenario of a
government agency that wants to collect some data and they want to create a digital
service to do this and we'll see how we can solve this by
creating an app using the alton 3 solutions
now these are some of the key features that we like that we want to support and these are
also some pain points from the existing platform that we would like to improve on
so what is an app in this context well an app is a digital service in the
form of a stand-alone application and this application exposes some apis it has some sort of
graphical user interface and it runs in a docker container
so to support this we have created an app template this is the starting point for
all of the apps the app template is built is a
net core mvc application completely standard and then we have
extended it with some supporting libraries these are projects that we
publish as nougat packages now nougat is dotnet's package manager
and these supporting libraries contain things like the standard apis that the apps should expose
as well as integration with the altin platform we've also added placeholders for custom
logic and a set of configuration files that the app developers can use to configure
the apps the app also refers to a front end
this is a react application that is loaded from a content delivery network at runtime
all of the apps use the same front-end by default and the front-end can then be configured
to work with the specific apps the front-end integrates with the app
itself via the apis that the app exposes so let's look a little bit at
how an app developer could actually customize the app
as i mentioned one of the ways to do this is through a set of configuration files and one of
the most important configurations that we set up is the process the process defines
the set of tasks that the end user that actually uses the app must go through
so for example if we look at i think back in our scenario of a government agency that wants to
collect data so the end user might have to for example fill in a form
this would be a data type task they might then have to confirm that their data is correct
so this would be a confirmation task finally they might need to wait for some
response from the agency that they are submitting their data to and this would be the feedback type task
so these are the three task types that we support and they can be combined in any way to
create a process now defining the process is done through
the process configuration file and when we set up our configuration files we tried where possible to use existing
standards for the format for the process we use the bpmn 2.0
standard this is an xml notation for defining processes uh
we've also used the zakimal standard for our authorization policies
and this is an xml standard for defining access control now authorization policies can be
applied to the entire app as a whole or to specific process tasks
so that was a little bit about setting up the app using the configuration files
now the app developers can of course also customize the apps
through code as i mentioned we set up some placeholders for custom logic now
this is for things like validation calculation or pre-filling of data
but this is really just the beginning app developers can really do anything
they want as long as they can put it into code for example they could fetch data from the altin platform
or from external sources they could create and expose apis and the list goes on and on and
really as i said if it can be coded it can be done
now let's take this one step further i said that the apps all use the same
front end by default and then that front end can be configured well imagine that this doesn't cut it
you can't configure the standard front end to do what you want it to do all right replace it with something
different since we just refer to the app front end from the app you can just refer to
something else and load it at runtime or drop the front end entirely and have
your end users go directly to the app via the apis
and if we go even further now nothing is really stopping you from doing
the same thing with the app template itself you could if it doesn't work for you you
could replace it with something different maybe even a java application
now personally i would not choose to replace our beautiful amazing.net app

if the standard template doesn't do it for you then of course it is possible to replace

of app templates using different technologies that can that you can choose from when

it now uh as we um uh
as we've said before we want the uis to be modern and they want them to work on both desktop and mobile
um and one of the ways to configure the ui is by creating a form for collecting
data so as juno mentioned we decided to build our own tool instead of using existing tools to do
this so we built it we built a drag and drop forms editor
using react and this forms editor has a library of available components
that can be dragged into the form layout and then configured now currently we only support very
simple forms with a single column layout and we do aim to expand on this
when an app developer works on developing on configuring a forum like this
the actual form configuration and the definition of the form is stored in a json layout file so this
is our form layout file and it defines how the form should look
at runtime the app frontend then parses this layout file and renders the form
now this configuration is for the data type tasks so forms are for
collecting data but we do have the possibility to configure views for the other task types as well
so that would be confirmation and feedback we have views for these and the app owners can then configure
the content that will be shown in these views
now so far i've talked about the apps but how do we actually develop apps into complete digital
services well this is done in the alton studio solution alton studio is made up of three parts
and we have the designer application this is the graphical user interface that app
app developers use to create and develop their apps this is what it looks like in
the designer application we have things like the forms builder that i just showed you and we have an editor for setting up
texts for language support we have some support for simple code
editing using an embedded code editor and of course deploy
now the designer application integrates with the repository application this is where all of the apps in alton
studio are stored the repository application is built on getty this is an open source code
hosting solution that uses git and it looks like this a little bit like
github now each app in alton studio is stored in a git repository
and when an app developer works on an app in the alt in studio solution
they are working on a clone of the central app repository and when they're done with their changes
they could push their changes to the app repository now this makes it easy for multiple
developers to work on the same app at the same time and all of the files are
version controlled just like normal source code we have set up a load balancer to route
between the repository application and the designer application based on the url that comes in
now building applications through a graphical user interface and drag and drop it's cool
unfortunately not all of the functionality of the apps is supported to be configured
through a graphical user interface in alton studio in addition some developers might
actually like to use their own tools especially when it comes to writing code so we support local development where
app developers can use their favorite tools to work on the apps so once an app is created it can be
cloned to your local computer and where you can work on it once you're done you can push it back up to the app
repository for deploy now one very important aspect of developing
an app which i haven't talked about yet is testing apps needs to be tested
and the apps need uh the alton platform solution to actually run so one possibility is to deploy the
app to a test environment where the alt-in platform solution is running however if you are just testing
while you are developing and testing incremental changes this could be very time consuming um
so in order to support local testing we have created a platform mock
now this can be downloaded and run in parallel with the apps in order to actually test the apps
locally on the fly while developing this platform mock is also used a lot by
the development team when we're developing new features for the apps
all right let's look at deploy apps are deployed from the alton studio solution to a

do not affect the apps of another agency and this is what allows us to provide
self-service deploys all the way to production
now deploy is a two-step process first we need to actually build the
application and this builds a docker image for the app
and then pushes it to an azure container registry and this is done via an azure devops

again done using an azure devops

authorizing access for every apps the apis and so on and this this is a sacrament 3.0

it's available in our source code and could be used in every elsewhere you can use a pdp

to talk a bit about our public cloud components and our architecture and azure
we're going to exemplify this by looking at how we deploy our microservices

one placed east and one placed west in the country this makes them the only large cloud
provider with data centers in norway given that they have two data centers
we're able to have redundancy within norwegian borders and this is great as we then can take on
application owners that have a requirement that they their data be stored within norway
another great thing about using the norwegian data centers is that we get a lower latency in the

and so the first step of course is source control we use github for all the code that
we're developing and giddy for all the code related to the applications
at this stage we also like to run analysis on our code so we use lgtm looks good to me for

and that's just a few of the tools that we're using and so once we have a new feature for
the platform or an application owner decides it's it's time to build their
app a build pipeline is triggered in azure devops
and so this build pipeline is made out of ready template tasks in azure devops
making them really easy to configure it's a two-step pipeline where the first
step is building a docker image and the second step is pushing that image to container registry
container registry is hosted in azure and this is where we store our live images
until we're ready to deploy the microservice and the two important things i'd like to point
out about the container registry the first point being that we are a
public platform and our users must be able to trust that their data is safe going back to the isolation principle
this is why we have a container registry for each of our application owners
where only their docker images are stored secondly a single docker image might be
deployed to multiple environments so both testing and production this is why we treat our container
registry and all the docker images as production resources meaning that we
set restrictions on what and who is able to access the resource as well as which availability we're
expecting and also which region we're hosting the resource in
so next step once we have the docker image in container registry and we're ready to deploy the microservice is that we trigger a
release pipeline this is also hosted in azure devops and this pipeline would use helm to
install the microservice on the cluster but i do have a confession to make before we take a closer look at the
release pipeline because we are an open source project and we really like mentioning it because
we really like that fact but truth be told we do have an additional repository which is protected
and this is where we store sensitive data such as helm charts and instrumentation keys for some of our
resources in azure and so this helm chart and the other
secrets are packed as an artifact and included into the release pipeline
that way what we see here is an overview of the release pipeline
for one of our platform components we can see that two artifacts are
included in the pipeline the first artifact is to identify which docker image we want to deploy
and the second artifact would be the helm charts from that repository i was just mentioning
so once we have the artifacts we're ready to deploy this microservice to one of our environments
and what we can see here are all of our environments listed up so in the first stage you'll find our
acceptance testing and load testing environments in the second in the second stage we
have the testing environment for our application owners and then finally we have production
and so for these various stages we have different triggers with regards to a platform component a
new release would go to the acceptance testing environments whenever a new docker container is
available or a docker image is available for our application owner testing
environments and also production we have weekly releases and we also have some manual checkpoints
prior to each release to ensure that that we have people at work in case something was to go wrong but the most
important thing about this release pipeline is the tasks that it completes
and the most important task is that the pipeline would would run a helm upgrade or helm install
task depending on if the microservice has been deployed previously or not
and the result of this task is that a new pod will spin up in the azure kubernetes services
cluster which brings us to the final step so a
new pod spins up in the kubernetes cluster and the referenced docker image is
pulled onto the pod and the microservice starts up and it's always
ensured that the microservice is fully up and running before we terminate any pre-existing
versions of that microservice this results in a deploy without any downtime
and so this is our overall process for good getting from code on github to running
services online and again it's the exact same process whether we're deploying our market
services or platform components or the applications of our users
